bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jessie Daniel Ames, July 17, 1942

div1.p: Hench appreciates Jessie Ames' answers to his numerous questions about Roger Ames. He requests that she donate some of the original fever charts for an planned exhibition at a Cuban museum.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jessie Daniel Ames, July 17, 1942
div1.opener:
July 17, 1942
Miss Jessie Daniel Ames
Box 485
Emory University, Georgia
Atlanta, Georgia
My dear Mrs. Ames:
div1.p:
I appreciate very greatly your last letter with the numerous
answers. I have had the fever charts photostated and I am returning them
by separate post. Did you know that these have been officially missing for
1o, these many years? I have searched high and low through the Archives
Building, Adjutant General's old record division, and the Surgeon General's
office, etc. with nary a trace of these fever records. You can imagine my
delight when I noticed in your portfolio your husband's letter to the Surgeon
General's office asking that the original charts, etc. be loaned to him.
Apparently they were either loaned to him by the Surgeon General's office
without making a note there as to where they were, or perhaps they were given
to him.

I wonder if I can make a very real request of you. I have amassed
quite a lot of material on the yellow fever story. Mrs. Lazear has given me
many of her husband's items, Generals Kean and Truby have contributed, the
Lazear relatives in Baltimore gave me a lot of stuff as did Walter Reed's
family; also Dr. Kelly who wrote up the life of Walter Reed handed over to me
all of the data which he had collected. They are to go into a permanent
yellow fever collection to be kept here in a special collection at the Mayo
Clinic, and if my plans materialize, to become the nucleus for a memorial
museum to be erected either at Camp Columbia or at Camp Lazear in Havana.
I think I told you I acquired title to the little Building No. 1 at Camp
Lazear and I am trying to raise the funds to buy the camp site and to have a
memorial building erected around the little building. On the walls of this
memorial building I plan to have various photographs, fever charts, maps and
other data connected with the yellow fever experiments. That was one of the
reasons I wanted a photograph of your husband--so that it could be placed there.
Would you be willing to present to this collection at least some of your fever
charts? Of course, the ones of greatest historical interest are those which
concern the first three cases--Carroll, Dean (XY) and Lazear. I wonder if your
present use of these fever charts has ended. While I realize that they would
have considerable sentimental value to your children, especially the fever chart
of your husband, I wonder if you agree with me that they ought to be placed in
a proper historical setting. If you feel this way about it, I would be only
too grateful for whatever documentary contribution you can make. In the mean-
time, however, as I have said, I am returning them all to you with very sincere
thanks. Were they to be contributed to the collection they would be shown in
the museum with the appropriate identification, as having been presented by you,
if you wish with an additional statement “In memory of Dr. Ames” or something to
that effect.

I am delighted to have the address of Dr. Ames' sister. I
shall write to her tactfully, in the manner you suggested.

I hope to be able to continue my investigations and study by
correspondence from my military station. We are always so busy here at the
Mayo Clinic that it is quite possible, despite the busy life in camp, I
will find that I have more time than I have had for some years.

I will be so grateful for the photostat of the Picayune article.
Rest assured that I am so impressed by the contribution you have made that
any information I can get about him from any source will be most welcome.

Presumably I leave here for about six weeks' training at Fort
Custer, Michigan next week, and then I expect to be sent to a station
hospital at Camp Carson, Colorado Springs. May I suggest, however, that
you write to me here for the time being until you hear from me from camp.
If plans materialize, I am to have the rank of lieutenant colonel and will
be chief of the medical service of the Camp Carson or some other large
station hospital. Somehow or other, my being a medical officer in the
army draws me closer to you and your husband and the rest of the men so
concerned with the yellow fever project.
div1.closer: Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
